cleaned_text: Powerful herbs for your dosha In Ayurveda, health is much more than the absence of disease. It is about bringing our body and mind into balance, along with our senses and spirit. Herbs offer a gentle approach to support this and bring the doshas back into balance. Find out which are the best herbs for the vata, pitta and kapha dosha. Take our [dosha quiz](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/arabia/en/dosha-quiz) first if you aren't sure of your mind-body type yet and be sure to read our [guide to Ayurvedic doshas](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/understanding-the-dosha) to learn more. Which herbs are best for me? Vata: Warming, grounding and nourishing herbs that aid digestion and calm anxious minds, like [ginger](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/the-benefits-of-ginger-and-how-we-source-it), [fennel](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/the-health-benefits-of-fennel), [chamomile](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/the-benefits-of-chamomile-tea)and [ashwagandha](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/what-is-ashwagandha) Pitta: Cooling, soothing and calming herbs that can help alleviate inflammation and support detoxification, like coriander, mint, rose and shatavari Kapha: Light, warming and aromatic herbs like turmeric, ginseng, triphala and black pepper Vata balancing herbs Composed of the space and air elements, [the vata dosha](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/vata) is responsible for all movement in the body. When vata is out of balance, you might start to feel spaced out and ungrounded, with possible bouts of anxiety and insomnia, as well as a 'nervous' digestion. You can use grounding, warming and calming herbs as part of an overall vata-balancing diet and lifestyle: Chamomile is renowned for relaxing the nervous system and [chamomile tea](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/hero-herbs/chamomile)is traditionally used to help calm and relax, often before bed. This herb does have other uses too - its mild and bitter flavour makes it perfect for digestion, helping to ease bloating and cramps, which vata types can be prone to. It's an easy plant to grow here in the UK, either in your garden, an allotment or a window box. Ginger and it's warmth brings vata types back into balance and is a universal medicine for many people around the world. Those with bad circulation might want to drink [ginger tea](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/hero-herbs/ginger)or chew on fresh ginger to bring some heat into the system and improve circulation. Ginger is also beneficial for vata-based digestive issues like bloating and constipation. It's always best to get hold of fresh ginger if you can as it has a better flavour and greater levels of anti-inflammatory properties. However, if you only have dried ginger, it will still be effective. Ashwagandha is an adaptogenic herb that [helps to calm and strengthen the nervous system](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/what-is-ashwagandha)and translates from Sanskrit as 'smell of a horse'. While that might not sound appealing, the translation refers to the stamina, strength and grace of a horse. Its Latin name, Withania somnifera, also gives a clue to its function as 'somnus' meaning sleep. [Ashwagandha's](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/hero-herbs/ashwagandha)reputation for promoting inner calm and core vitality makes this the perfect herb for addressing today's lifestyle demands, which can increase vata in our system Try Pukka's [Relax tea](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/products/relax-tea) blend, with soothing herbs like chamomile, and marshmallow. Pukka's [After Dinner](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/products/after-dinner-tea) and also keeping this dosha strong, calm and grounded. Pitta balancing herbs [Pitta](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/pitta) represents the fire and water elements and is responsible for digestion and metabolism of both food and inflammation. When pitta becomes aggravated you may experience heart burn, skin rashes, hot flushes, inflammation or irritability. Soothing, cooling and calming herbs help pacify this: Mint is a key herb for balancing pitta. There are so many varieties of mint including spearmint, field mint and peppermint. All these varieties have a sweet taste and help soothe inner heat. As well as suppressing aggravated pitta, there's now evidence that suggest mint could improve digestion, enhance respiratory health and provide general health benefits as an antioxidant. Mint is perennial and very easy to grow in the UK. In fact, you'll have trim it regularly to ensure it doesn't take over your garden - growing in a pot is strongly advised. Coriander is pungent, sweet and slightly bitter, and is a wonderful remedy for clearing irritating heat from the body and helping to clear the digestive tract. The leaves can be made into delicious fresh chutneys or to accompany a curry Shatavari belongs to the wild asparagus family and can reduce pitta and vata, but increase kapha. Its key uses are to rejuvenate and act as a female reproductive tonic. This herb is available in our [Womankind tea.](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/products/womankind-tea) Pukka's [Mint Refresh tea](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/products/mint-refresh-tea) contains peppermint leaf, rose, coriander seed, hibiscus flower, fennel seed and licorice, which sooth and calm pitta types. Pukka's [Womankind tea](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/products/womankind-tea) both calms and cools pitta and can help with inflammation and irritation. Kapha balancing herbs [Kapha](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/wellbeing-articles/kapha) represents water and earth and is responsible for maintaining the structure and lubrication of the mind-body physiology. When kapha becomes excessive, you might experience congestion, sinus problems, weight gain and tiredness. Light, heating and aromatic varieties are some of the best herbs for the kapha dosha to maintain balance: Turmeric is a pharmacy unto itself. As a wealth of scientific studies has found, this golden spice contains potent anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that are valuable in preventing and treating a variety of diseases. In Ayurvedic medicine, turmeric is an important detoxifying agent. Since it possesses the bitter, pungent, and astringent tastes and is mildly heating, it is useful in balancing excess Kapha in the mind-body system. You'll find this herb in a wide selection of our [turmeric teas](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/hero-herbs/turmeric). Ginseng with its heating qualities can help reduce kapha but increase pitta. Ginseng is a powerful herb and its Latin name, panax, comes from the Greek 'panacea' or 'heal all'; it provides both a mental and physical boost, while building core energy levels within the adrenal glands. Ginseng gives kapha types boundless energy Black pepper's heating, light, drying and sharp properties help to reduce kapha and vata and increase pitta. This herb is easy to throw into most recipes and is good at clearing fat from the digestive system and lungs. Kapha types can try a daily tonic by mixing a third of a teaspoon of pepper with a teaspoon of honey and allowing it to dissolve on the tongue. This is especially helpful when you're eating foods that might aggravate kapha like cheese, wheat or potatoes Pukka's [Revitalise tea](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/products/revitalise-tea) was blended with kapha in mind as it contains cinnamon, ginger, green tea, black pepper, elderflower and orange peel to energise. Spicy, warming teas, like [Three Ginger](https://www.pukkaherbs.com/uk/en/products/three-ginger-tea), can also balance excess kapha.
